Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Expectation2: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation2: A crane is holding a heavy beam in position, and you must immediately help guide it into place before it can be secured.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as the foreman shouted for everyone to get ready—the crane was lowering the steel beam, and I was one of the few trained to guide it into place. I glanced at the screen: it was Sam, my best friend. The message was frantic—her car had broken down on the highway, and she was scared, stranded in the dark, begging me to come get her right away. My heart pounded. I could hear the crane’s engine humming, the crew waiting for me to grab my gloves and step up. If I left now, the whole team would be stuck, the beam swaying dangerously, the schedule thrown off. But if I stayed, Sam would be alone, maybe in danger, counting on me like she always had. My hands shook as I stared at my phone, torn between the urgent call of friendship and the heavy responsibility of the job. Both sides needed me, right now, and I felt split in two, unable to move.
